channel.title: NYT > Science
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Why Whales Don’t Choke
item.description: Scientists have discovered a new anatomical structure that allows lunge-feeding whales to take in massive amounts of water without choking.
item.dc:creator: Sam Jones
item.media:description: A humpback whale lunge feeding off Vancouver Island in Canada.

item.title: U.S. Drops Its Case Against M.I.T. Scientist Accused of Hiding China Links
item.description: Gang Chen, a professor of mechanical engineering, was arrested a year ago, accused of concealing his affiliations with Chinese government institutions.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Barry and Katie Benner
item.media:description: Gang Chen, an M.I.T. scientist, was arrested in 2021 as part of the China Initiative, a government anti-espionage effort that has come under criticism for singling out scientists of Chinese heritage.

item.title: A New Map of the Sun’s Local Bubble
item.description: At the edge of a vast region devoid of gas and dust, scientists find an explanation for “how all nearby star formation began.”
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye

item.title: Sprawling Coral Reef Resembling Roses Is Discovered Off Tahiti
item.description: The reef, which is just under two miles long and is in “pristine” condition, was found by a team of divers mapping the ocean floor for UNESCO.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.media:description: A coral reef resembling a bed of roses was discovered off the coast of Tahiti.

item.title: ‘Major Discovery’ Beneath Antarctic Seas: A Giant Icefish Breeding Colony
item.description: Scientists discovered a mammoth nesting ground with an estimated 60 million icefish nests in the Weddell Sea.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Imbler

item.title: Sometimes, Life Stinks. So He Invented the Nasal Ranger.
item.description: For Chuck McGinley, an engineer who devised the go-to instrument for measuring odors, helping people understand what they smell is serious science.
item.dc:creator: Winston Choi-Schagrin
item.media:credit: Caroline Yang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chuck McGinley with his Nasal Ranger, a design inspired by the shape of the Haleakala volcano in Hawaii.

item.title: Checking Privilege in the Animal Kingdom
item.description: Researchers say the human concepts of intergenerational wealth and inequality are useful for studying some animals’ behavior.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Preston
item.media:description: Check your privilege, squirrel.

item.title: How European Royals Once Shared Their Most Important Secrets
item.description: Recent research highlights the use of letterlocking techniques by Queen Elizabeth, Catherine de’ Medici and Mary Queen of Scots.
item.dc:creator: William J. Broad
item.category: Elizabeth I, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: A letter from Mary Queen of Scots, sent on Feb. 8, 1587, to Henry III, king of France. The letter was written and locked just hours before Mary was executed for treason.

item.title: Deborah Nickerson, Pioneering Genome Researcher, Dies at 67
item.description: Using the Human Genome Project as her guide, she helped find genes responsible for cardiovascular disease, autism and a rare disorder called Miller syndrome.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir

item.title: Kidneys From a Genetically Altered Pig Are Implanted in a Brain-Dead Patient
item.description: Surgeons at the University of Alabama at Birmingham said they hoped to start clinical trials with kidney patients later this year.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin

item.title: Predictions Favored Solar Over Wind Power. What Happened?
item.description: One lesson: Renewable technology benefits from early, consistent government support.
item.dc:creator: Lois Parshley

item.title: ‘Build Back Better’ Hit a Wall, but Climate Action Could Move Forward
item.description: Some Democrats want to forge ahead with a stand-alone climate bill, but their solution could mean abandoning other parts of President Biden’s agenda.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport and Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: “I think it’s clear that we would be able to get support for the $500 billion plus for energy and the environment,” President Biden said of Congress on Wednesday.

item.title: Most ‘Havana Syndrome’ Cases Unlikely Caused by Foreign Power, C.I.A. Says
item.description: A report concluded that most cases have environmental or medical causes, but the government remains focused on investigating two dozen incidents that remain unexplained.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: About 1,000 cases of the mysterious illness that initially appeared at the U.S. Embassy in Havana have been reported, but of those, the C.I.A. is now focusing on about two dozen unexplained incidents.

item.title: Why Are Men More Likely to Die of Covid? It’s Complicated.
item.description: Sex differences in Covid death rates vary widely from state to state, suggesting they are rooted in behavior as well as biology.
item.dc:creator: Azeen Ghorayshi
item.media:description: A Covid-19 patient in the intensive care unit of a hospital in La Mesa, Calif.

item.title: Sara McLanahan, Who Studied Single Motherhood, Dies at 81
item.description: A Princeton sociologist and a single mother herself, she brought her own experience to her wide body of scholarly work.
item.dc:creator: Annabelle Williams

item.title: In Sewage, Clues to Omicron’s Surge
item.description: Tracking the virus in wastewater is helping some cities and hospitals respond to the most recent wave of the coronavirus, but a more coordinated national effort is needed, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes and Sabrina Imbler
item.media:description: Workers in Monaco took sewage water samples to detect coronavirus concentration in the area in 2021.

item.title: How Anxiety Can Benefit Us
item.description: There are several benefits to having an internal alarm system, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron

item.title: New Research Shows How Health Risks to Children Mount as Temperatures Rise
item.description: The first nationwide study on rising temperatures and younger Americans found that hotter days were associated with more visits to emergency rooms.
item.dc:creator: Winston Choi-Schagrin
item.media:description: A misting station in Queens in August. National research shows that children face particular dangers during heat waves.

item.title: Searching for Pfizer’s Paxlovid Pills When Mom Got Covid
item.description: The experience showed how hard it is for many people to get potentially lifesaving treatments.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins
item.media:credit: Alex Welsh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mary Ann Neilsen, the author’s mother, holding her last Paxlovid pills while recovering from Covid-19.

item.title: Biden Administration Announces Plan to Spend Billions to Prevent Wildfires
item.description: The plan is an expensive one, but it is only partially funded.
item.dc:creator: Alyssa Lukpat
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Caldor fire in Eldorado National Forest near Pollock Pines, Calif., last year.

item.title: Here’s What Scientists Know About the Tonga Volcano Eruption
item.description: The explosion probably won’t cool the planet as some previous eruptions have done, but it could affect weather in the short term.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:description: The Hunga Tonga-Hunga Ha’apai volcano, off the coast of Tonga, on Friday.

item.title: After Tonga's Volcano Eruption, Worries Grow About Covid Exposure
item.description: Aid workers risk bringing in a virus Tonga has so far kept out. But there are more immediate problems, as its government confirmed in its first statement since the disaster.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave, Isabella Kwai and Eric Nagourney
item.media:credit: Fuerza de Defensa de Nueva Zelanda
item.media:description: Vista de una densa caída de ceniza en Nomuka, Tonga, el lunes

item.title: In Arkansas, Trans Teens Await an Uncertain Future
item.description: Even as the medical community grapples with how best to provide care to transgender adolescents, some states seek to ban it outright.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Imbler
item.media:credit: Liz Sanders for The New York Times

item.title: A California City Is Overrun by Crows. Could a Laser Be the Answer?
item.description: In a move befitting its Silicon Valley setting, the city of Sunnyvale, Calif., will aim a laser at 1,000 birds that have overwhelmed the downtown area during the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Alyssa Lukpat
item.category: Laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation)
item.media:description: Crows fly near downtown Sunnyvale, Calif.

item.title: The Eerie, Lunar Nothingness of Namibia’s Skeleton Coast
item.description: The stretch of coastline in southwest Africa is a strange and beautiful reminder that, in the end, we are powerless against nature and time.
item.dc:creator: Genna Martin
item.media:description: The C34 highway, along Namibia’s coast, is barely distinguishable from the surrounding desert.

item.title: The C.D.C.’s New Challenge? Grappling With Imperfect Science
item.description: The Omicron coronavirus variant is moving much faster than researchers can, worsening a longstanding problem: The agency must make tough decisions with scant data.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Rochelle Walensky, the C.D.C. director, right, and Dr. Anthony Fauci of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, during a Senate hearing in November.

item.title: How The mRNA Vaccines Were Made: Halting Progress and Happy Accidents
item.description: The stunning Covid vaccines manufactured by Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna drew upon long-buried discoveries made in the hopes of ending past epidemics.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata and Benjamin Mueller
item.media:credit: Johnathon Kelso for The New York Times
item.media:description: A 3-D plaster model of a coronavirus spike protein in the office of Dr. Barney Graham of the Vaccine Research Center of the National Institutes of Health.

item.title: Howard Solomon, 94, Dies; His Business Success Had a Personal Connection
item.description: After one of his sons fell into a deep depression, he helped him recover. He later licensed an antidepressant that was a boon to his pharmaceutical company.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir

item.title: The Kunga Was a Status Symbol Long Before the Thoroughbred
item.description: A new study finds the first known instance of a human-engineered hybrid, bred from a donkey and a Syrian wild ass 4,500 years ago.
item.dc:creator: James Gorman

item.title: For Coronavirus Testing, the Nose May Not Always Be Best
item.description: As Omicron spreads, some experts are calling for a switch to saliva-based tests, which may detect infections days earlier than nasal swabs do.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A saliva Covid-19 testing site at the University of Minnesota Field House in Minneapolis.

item.title: More Young Kids Are Getting Sick From Cannabis Edibles
item.description: As states legalize cannabis, a growing number of children are inadvertently consuming marijuana-infused foods.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron
item.category: American Assn of Poison Control Centers
item.media:credit: Chona Kasinger for The New York Times
item.media:description: To protect children from accidentally ingesting marijuana edibles, some states have passed laws governing how these foods can be packaged and presented.
